vertex.media: In episode two, Stephan's financial crisis sparks a flurry of emotions about everyone's self worth.
In episode three, the Board reminds itself to slow down, and David discusses the past lives of his wife.
In episode four, Bonita reveals a special connection with Dan, and we learn Eurydice's life goal.

vertex.title: **BEHIND THE SCENES** with Hal Cannon and Taki Telonidis
vertex.media: Young riders sing a song of encouragement to their horses at Dawa's Ger Camp.
The Egshiglen Ensemble play a lament for a mother far away milking her animals.
Yak milking song sung by a woman named Lenna who was encountered along the road to Genghis Khan's ancient capital of Karakorum.

vertex.title: **BEHIND THE SCENES** with Aaron Ximm
vertex.media: Patrick Perdue had this to say about his OMV, Implosions and Cheers / Greensboro, NC: "In May 2005 there was a large turn-out for the demolition of the Burlington Industries building, a six-story steel structure. A demolition like this hadn't occurred in Greensboro in decades. Air horns warned of the impending implosion fifteen seconds before the demo team set off two hundred pounds of 'bang.'"

Of his OMV, Manual Typewriters Alfresco / Calcutta, India, Kevin T. Allen said, "I was looking for a film library in the center of town when I passed a row of government buildings and hundreds of people queued up outside. They waited at makeshift carts and stands to dictate their offical paperwork to men using manual typewriters. The sound of the typewriters in the context of the bustling city sidewalk was beautifully surreal."

Siamack Sioshansi says he was inspired to record Call and Response / Central Mexico when, "driving through the highlands of Michoacan, I heard the soft sound of a band in a distant field. A steep ride down a dirt road later, we joined a procession of two hundred people celebrating Saint Jude's festival. My recording documents the call-and-response between the singers and band that went on for over an hour."

vertex.media: Imagine There's No Feature (re-imagined by the 2008-09 EBU Master School participants) Along with the MP3 of this song, EBU MS student Susanne Franzmeyer advised: "Please be aware that the text was written by the group spontaneously in a restaurant after a few drinks, and that the text sometimes is really nonsense or is based on some inside jokes ("it's just my inner wind" refers for example to an expression that one character of Tomica's protagonists always used, who is a digeridoo player). I really don't know if it's interesting for other people, but you can decide that better than me."

vertex.media: Here's an excerpt from "Rodeo Red," a sound poem included on Crosstalk: American Speech Music, an anthology of sound poetry and sound-text compositions presented by the Obadikes.
In this excerpt of a live performance at the Bowery Poetry Club, the Obadikes perform part of The Sour Thunder, sing a country song, and Mendi recites a poem.

vertex.title: **Behind the Scenes with producer Lance Dann**
Extra
vertex.media: Inspired by this article by musician (and sonic hero to many) Brian Eno, the Kitchen Sisters closed out the Conference by leading the room in a rousing hootenanny. A full band materialized (seemingly) out of thin air, with 350 radio producers enthusiastically singing "16 Tons" and "I Get By With A Little Help From My Friends." The start of a new TCF Conference tradition? We certainly hope so.

vertex.media: Barton Girdwood sits at a coffeeshop in Indianapolis listening to his friend's Odyssey-esque attempt to get his pocket watch repaired. Excerpts from Paul Harding's "Tinkers" are woven throughout.

Don Fidel opened a restaurant in Chicago, but for his family it was more than just a restaurant. It was their home, a home full of memories. Eddie Suarez and his family remember their grandfather through memories of this restaurant.

In this excerpt from Stokowski: A Portrait for Radio, the conductor reflects on the international spirit of music and the effect of technology on shared cultures.
In this excerpt from Stokowski: A Portrait for Radio, the conductor contemplates cavemen, aliens, and their notions about "the creative life."
